criticReviews.criticPost: However much corruption and amorality Murder in the First uncovers, however many times it executes the sentimental heart-tug, it promises, in this second season, only a mild intellectual puzzle stretched over far too many episodes.
If the second run of this utility player mirrors the performance of the first, English and Mulligan should be prepared to patrol the streets of San Francisco a while longer.
The show is merely solid-albeit wholly unambitious-and when there are so many more exciting shows on the horizon, solid and unambitious don't really cut it.
Recent serialized yarns have surpassed this, which has the feel of a crime-of-the-week procedural but doesn't have the payoff at each episode's end.
If the pilot is any indication, it should be perfect summer-worthy viewing and a good match with Major Crimes. I'm in.
If Bochco can re-create the twisty legal action that was a hallmark of [L.A. Law], Murder in the First will be worth the 10 hours.
TNT may be selling the single-case-per-season timeline of its new detective drama, but amid television's recent age of Aquarius, Murder in the First stands out mostly for its simplicity.
Diggs and Robertson ground the show in interesting characters at its core, allowing scene stealers like Schiff and Cromwell to do what they do so well.
Overall, the premiere was entertaining. The multiple murders and people involved have set up for a season-long mystery that I'm looking forward to seeing solved.
The action here is both meaty and mostly realistic, if the twists and turns in the main characters' personal lives are a bit soapy.
Murder in the First is an immediately engaging crime drama boasting a deep cast and crisp direction. It's the ideal newcomer to team with Major Crimes.
Every one in the cast is thoroughly adequate, and Murder has low ambitions and satisfies them easily.
What was bracing in the '90s has become painfully generic now, when television is loaded down with more case-of-the-season shows than it knows what to do with.
The premiere episode of Murder in the First is somewhat dull, particularly anytime the plot strays from the case to the home lives of the detectives.
Little about Murder in the First feels fresh, much less first.
The characters may be shallow, but that doesn't keep the show from giving the easy pleasures of reading a quickie mystery novel.
The show is pretty good, though. It doesn't have the artistic pretensions of many of the other series of its type but that means it also doesn't have to live up to an overly inflated self-image.
Like most of the best cable shows, Murder in the First strips the production and the cast down to the essentials, then executes them well.
The show is generally well written, expertly directed (Thomas Schlamme of West Wing directs the pilot) and most of the performances are solid.
Murder in the First starts out slow and steady with the tension building with each episode, but the characters will grab you from the start.
Among the things one notices about the new Murder in the First is that it's not in his customary New York or Los Angeles but San Francisco and, unlike that city, is as flat as a pancake.
Good, cleanly told newcomer that can be a bit pokey.

The cast does the best they can with the material, but considering how unbelievable the writing is, there's little they can do to lessen the feeling that we're watching a soap opera with nice production values, plus nudity and swearing.
On the whole, I'd rather watch my car overheat in rush hour traffic.
Crash has a noirish appeal, and ambitions to tell a big story.
The acting doesn't exactly induce gaper's block.
Leaves you wondering if the whole setup might not simply work better as a movie.
The show clearly wants to say something complicated about race and class in Los Angeles, but a number of the situations and characters on the show feel like situations and people we've seen before.
At once schematic and preachy, it never indicates the stakes - either for its "diverse" players or for you.
It's possible that Crash will end up saying something interesting about racism, cops, housewives, or Los Angeles. But I doubt it.
Unless Crash the show improves rapidly, it'll just provide more fuel for the people angered that the movie beat out Brokeback Mountain and Munich for the big prize.
Crash, based upon the Oscar-winning movie, won't prompt much rubbernecking.
Crash, based on the Oscar-winning movie, is a show that's madly in love with its own daring and importance.
The new drama Crash struggles mightily to appear slick and sophisticated and special, but the whole elaborate mess is just as leaden and obvious as the Oscar-winning movie upon which it's based.
Once you've seen the movie, why else would you want to be hit in the head with a sledgehammer?
Given the uneven ride, high gas prices are about the only incentive to stay home and, er, bump into it.
With six separate storylines following characters not in the movie, Crash could become a complicated serial.
... Pete Holmes has successfully created a likable standup comic (which is tough enough to create) whose struggle is something we root for.
It stands as an example of a series that the premium cable environment allows to breathe and grow and develop.
Crashing works because there's just something so inherently cozy about watching a person trying to piece together the A through L so they can eventually get to Z.
For anyone already hooked on Crashing, Season 2 should keep them coming back, and new or unfamiliar viewers will find their patience through Season 1 adequately rewarded.
[Pete] Holmes fills his character with warmth and understanding; you want to root for him. However, for a series about comedy it feels like it actually needs more of it.
What does Crashing bring to that overflowing table of meta-commentary about the stand-up life? Well, Pete Holmes.
Watch Crashing if you're feeling lonely but don't feel like leaving your house. And then make your friends come over and rewatch it all with you.
"Crashing" bore might be a good summary for this comedy in which little ever happens.
Painful laughs in this honest, scathing couchsurfer comedy.
Crashing deserves an audience. It is clever, witty and genuinely funny, working from the idea that the stand-up comedian is a kind of pastor to his unruly flock.
None of this draws a chuckle.
Crashing works because Holmes is so sweet (there's really no other word for it) that we root for him every step of the way.

Because it has a genuine interest in exploring what is funny and why comedians are compelled to do what they do, Crashing overcomes its rampant similarities to the stand-up-centric shows that have come before.
Crashing grows with its hero, starting off as more likable than funny, but steadily getting more laughs as it goes along.

Much like Holmes on stage, Crashing is working on finding itself. The premiere is solid and certainly has some strong humor at the expense of down-on-his-luck Holmes, but subsequent episodes get stronger and stronger.
It all makes for a perfect showcase for the star.

Pete has yet to figure out that the art of winning an audience is perfected through enthusiastically failing again and again. Crashing shows that Holmes has already mastered that lesson and has moved on to quietly, honestly killing it.
On top of it all, Holmes proves himself to be a strong actor and an immensely likable leading man.
Crashing has enough mostly gentle amusements to keep it on track.
Crashing is damn funny and very likeable, make no mistake about it, but it probably won't leave a lasting impression.
Crashing feels like just another sad-clown story centered on a white male comic.

At its best, though, Crashing is a kind of corrective, and an honest one at that. Comedy need not be only the refuge of the cynic. It also has room for figures like Holmes, for whom the craft is less a burden than a blast.

Crashing, Holmes' new half-hour comedy series, is exactly the material I expected from Holmes; a good-natured, funny, but not quite laugh-out-loud funny, inessential entry into the "comedy shows about comedy" genre.
The show works as a sort of trial by fire comedy about a guy who just might need to experience a bit of pain in order to become a better comedian.
Fargo's creator, Noah Hawley, took us on many diversions this season: into the past, into the woods, into action movie territory. Yet it was the comedy of character we will remember.
That might be why Fargo's spark feels a trifle faded; we've seen so many of these characters and elements in different configurations before.
This season was just as strong if not stronger than any other season, but it rarely gave you the answers. It asked you to think.
In this third season, two characters rise to the top as protagonists worth cheering on: Minnesotan police chief Gloria Burgle and Nikki Swango, a street-smart ex-con.
It's as if Fargo is riffing on its resemblance to itself; as if the echoes between seasons and with the film are filtering into the plot, and building resonance out of the mix-ups.

Season 3 seemed like it had finally, decisively broken from its predecessors on both TV and in film - particularly when Mary Elizabeth Winstead's scammer emerged as the season's complicated, gray-area-dwelling hero.
This was a superb season and, earlier reservations swept aside, probably the Fargo I'd be most inclined to watch again.
It's all perfectly enjoyable in that peculiar Fargo way where you know that something kooky will inevitably be followed by something monstrous. You can also tick off a few more boxes.

It took a while to build up steam, but once the hammer dropped midway through, some fantastic and surreal elements kicked in, characters began to feel genuine instead of flat, and some devastating sequences delivered a superb story.
Overall, it feels less like an engaging story and more a series of grotesques. I'm sure it's genius. I just don't want to watch it.
Despite a too-slow opening episode, it's now settled to a taut thrum of wit, blood, intrigue and what Nikki likes to call "unfathomable pinheadery"
I'll certainly be along for the ride.
What really makes this season is Ewan McGregor. Twice.
With its sly wit and visual flair, the third series of Fargo is already shaping up to be the best yet. Darn tootin'? You betcha.
For me, the beauty of this show is the fact it is about ordinary people, doing ordinary things, who get drawn into extraordinary situations through a series of wrong but understandable decisions.
This is simply the classiest piece of TV drama around. It's instantly entertaining, even if you've never seen any of it before and have never heard of the Coen brothers or that movie called Fargo.
All in all, a fine start to the season so far, with plenty of surprises to come, no doubt, if past seasons are any indication.
The statuesque Winstead proves why she is a favorite of indie film directors and television producers - Nikki Swango could be her breakout role.
So far, very Fargo-ian.
The acting here is as good as the writing, and the visuals - built, as with season one, around the isolated snow and ice of the Midwest - are like paintings that move.
Fargo 2.0 promises to be every bit as fun, surprising and thought-provoking as the original.
It's weird and wonderful and elegantly done. Expect lots of snow, blood and great dark humour.
The fingerprints of writer Noah Hawley and director Randall Einhorn​, who worked on the first season, are all over this, and that could explain the smoother transition from season one to season two.
What is most surprising about Season 2 is that it's somehow even better.
It's the rarest of feats that the second season of a brilliant television show outdoes the first, but Noah Hawley's Fargo has done just that.
Excruciating, shocking and hilarious, it sends mixed messages to the stomach muscles; I'm tensing and squirming and properly belly-laughing, all at the same time.
Fargo 2.0 wins you over with its terrific performances and a plot that keeps churning and twisting as it reveals curious new angles.
Congratulations, Fargo team! It's still incredible. No True Detective disappointment here.
Clearly, season one was no fluke. Once again, Fargo is just about the best thing on TV - and that includes streaming.
If for no other reason, you should watch it because it is a completely unique experience.
Fargo, the TV show, has more than developed its own identity and is fully capable of standing on its own.

Through the first four episodes, Fargo remains a terrific thriller laced with black humor. Viewers will see where some aspects of the story are heading, but they won't necessarily guess how the show will move its characters from point A to point B.

It's drolly funny, it's effectively creepy, it's tightly plotted, it's loaded with beautifully defined characters, and, somehow, with its Midwestern accents and scuzzy diners, it's all peculiarly and specifically American.

At one point in the first episode, one of the Kansas City operatives (played by Brad Garrett) somewhat dismissively describes Floyd this way: "She's tough but, you know, a girl." Yes, well, we'd be foolish to underestimate her. Or this show.
Following a splendid first season, the anthology-like Fargo starts a second season even more assured, surprising, funny, out there, brutal and addictive.
It works. Give or take The Leftovers, this is the best show of the fall.

Violence, deadpan humor and observational oddity mix on this show in a way that no other current series quite matches - not Bates Motel, not Salem, not even that other FX curiosity, American Horror Story.
Season two's first episode delivered smartly written, fascinating characters and set up a compelling story of murder and rival mobs.

The show is packed with plot, yet creator-writer Noah Hawley is so confident in his storytelling, the show feels leisurely -- there's always time to tuck in a small laugh-line or a neat little character detail.
Baked into every word, every gesture, is an implicit recognition of that brutal Fargo credo: People can be cruel, stupid, mean and unintentionally funny, even the nice ones.
Let it all boil and stay in on Sundays for the next two months. It'll be worth it. Treat yourself to a little bit of Minnesota nice.
It may start like Coens fan-fiction, but Fargo showrunner Noah Hawley quickly proves he has moves of his own.
It's a perfect joy, and it's a good while since I set my digibox thing to "record whole series", but this promises phenomenally much.
The show may (inevitably) lack the somber beauty of the Coens' meticulous compositions, but it nonetheless makes for good-looking, borderline-cinematic television.
The new Fargo... seemed to be brimming with characters and stories all its own.
What could have been a disaster, enraging Fargo aficionados, is a respectful homage, and should quench a thirst they had half forgotten they have.
Neither prequel, sequel or remake, this Fargo is instead a tonal accompaniment, a little more than kin, a little less than kind and a whole new breed of television.
This new Fargo is a worthy companion piece to the film.

A whole new constellation of characters is set against this familiar backdrop, playing out new tales of sordid activity in Bemidji, Minn., where the Minnesota nice is often punctured by bursts of violence and pain.
It's easy to lose yourself as I did in this world of endless snow, hopelessly flat lands, coffee shops, down jackets, small town facades, brutality, blood, drugs and slaughter.
Fargo can't help but live in the shadow of Fargo-but it seems quite happy there, messing around with similar ideas and characters while adding a tongue-in-cheek twist to the proceedings.
What I find to be best about Fargo... is how well it builds the world in which it's set rather convincingly and rather quickly.
You should overlook the shortcomings and enjoy the series on its own otherwise considerable merits, chief among them, of course, Billy Bob Thornton.
It's the kind of thing we've seen before in many a Coen brothers film, yet it never fails to disturb. If the slow roll-out is any indication, there are far more interesting developments to come.
This Fargo is too often tedious, a bit of a surprise considering the talent assembled here.

Others may praise the verbose slog that was True Detective or the uninvolving history of Turn, but for sheer entertainment value and constant surprise, no new program is better than this 10-part limited series adaptation of the Coen brothers' 1996 film.
Something wickedly delicious this way comes.
Fargo the series cannot recapture that fission, but it is enjoyable, funny, and, something TV rarely is, weird.
Big in scope, morbid hilarity and intrigue, Fargo's series premiere episode "The Crocodile's Dilemma" excellently sets up the rest of the season.
I'm almost halfway through and still have no idea where the next hour will take me. What delicious anticipation. Fargo may not be your dream destination, but I bet you'll want to go to there.
There was a refreshing dose of confidence present in "I Know What You Did Last Summer" that was largely absent last season.
Scream certainly brought it for the first episode of the season.

Though it remains to be seen whether this season will wrap up the mystery of the new killer in a way that's much more thrilling than in season 1, Scream season 2 certainly seems to have avoided many of the tropes of most horror sequels.
All in all, a solid enough premiere, though a lot will depend on how this plays out over the season, obviously.
Sporadically clever and requisitely gory - but still awkward and forced - more than ever, Scream the TV series will work wonders if you can just forget Scream the movie series ever happened.

There are one or two gory and well-mounted horror sequences, some smart lines, intermittently sharp commentary on online bullying, but Scream: The TV Series is a mostly dull and frustrating experience.

An incredibly MTV-in-2015 way to unravel a mystery: ridiculous, meme-obsessed, self-mocking, and fun if you don't think about it too much. Which basically sums up the first season of the network's Scream.
...(not) the impactful one-two punch (ending) one would have hoped for...the plot and the denouement end up better than three of the four seasons of American Horror Story...
Suspenseful and fun, this new MTV show is a real scream.
Most of my issue with the pilot comes from execution; ostensibly, they took what was best about Scream and tried to clumsily bend it to the confines of a television show.
Extreme graphic violence in TV retread of slasher series.
MTV's television series based on the popular franchise has the same exact archly self-aware tone, but the novelty is long gone, and what we're left with is pointless homage.
The biggest hindrance the program faces, though, might be in the visual limitations its medium affords.
Scream is self-aware - not only of its genre, but of its intended audience.
It often feels pretty, well, MTV, in a cliche sense, with a bevy of attractive, vapid characters acting in a rather stilted manner.
If you just know the plot of the original Scream, just take that and strip it to its most basic, generic parts until you get this.
Right from the first scene there's a unique energy to the piece. It doesn't feel like a knock-off or a cheap tie-in. It's a horror movie in weekly series form.

Luxe environments mixed with bitchy teen entitlement and karmic vengeance drive Scream beyond its slasher-exploitation film genesis to a stylish metaphor about a new generation's excesses and mean-girl cruelty.

MTV's TV adaptation of Scream updates the franchise with new characters and trendy references to Instagram, YouTube and texting, but it leaves out the snark and spirit that made the big-budget slasher film franchise so memorable.
I will not be sticking around, as a matter of taste; but I will not be standing in your way.
MTV is wrong when it says, "You can't do a slasher film as a TV series." What they should have said is, "We can't do it, but someone could."
Whether Scream can overcome Noah's legitimate concerns about adapting a slasher movie for TV remains to be seen. But tonight's premiere gets the show off to a strong creative start.

Once the foul deed happens, though, Scream, perhaps out of necessity, shifts to a more conventional teen-drama mode, introducing an assortment of characters, most of whom, one suspects, should be prepared to get shish-kebabbed before it's all over.
You gotta like any high school drama that starts with the mean girl getting stalked and stabbed to death beside her swimming pool.
Scream is exactly what you'd expect. It may also be exactly what you want.
The characters feel like people you want to watch because of how out there they are. The hospital has a life of its own that I am excited to get to the bottom of.
The season premiere still feels hopeful, even if it is just a little bit. The writing, truly, does seem better. And John Stamos! That's something, right?
Though Scream Again took a hot minute to get going, once it did, it was entertaining enough.

Scream Queens season 2 hasn't skipped a beat, and if you enjoyed its campy ridiculousness last season, this one promises more of the same. It's wacky, it's funny, and at times thrilling in a way only the best slashers can ever be.
Kirstie Alley was easily the best addition to the Scream Queens Universe(TM), even if we learned literally nothing about her character in this first hour.
Season one had its toes dipped in reality for the most part, but season two's first episode rarely flirted with the real world.
We're already coming back for season two, even if we have no idea where these characters could possibly go from here. It'll probably be fun to find out, though.

Ryan Murphy's Scream Queens is exactly what you'd expect a series from Ryan Murphy called Scream Queens to be. It's a blend of everything that's campy and bright about Glee and dark and grimy about American Horror Story.
Scream Queens still manages to be endlessly watchable.
Shiny, gory and whip-smart, Scream Queens thus attempted to pummel the viewer into submission with sheer, rictus-grinning relentlessness. And it worked.
A fun and campy series that will work until the acid jokes run out. [Full review in Spanish]
A pop culture bomb directed at teens that more than one adult can enjoy. [Full review in Spanish]
Let's call it right now: Scream Queens is already looking like the smartest move Ryan Murphy's ever made - it has all the best elements of Glee and American Horror Story, but it tops them both.
It's a fairly entertaining, but completely confusing, case of whiplash.
The whole time I watched, I was either laughing out loud, or feeling guilty for laughing out loud.
For a two-hour episode with plenty of blood, sexual tension and five 'dead' characters, not much else happens.
Of course, coherence might not be what one looks for in a Ryan Murphy joint. But "Scream Queens' is just exhausting
For this two-hour block of set up, Grace's first days at college were as hilariously on-formula as a game of Pocket Gem's Episodes...
Not only does the show play well, but it looks great doing it, too.
Really, Ryan Murphy productions have bled together more and more as the years go by, and Scream Queens feels like the pinnacle of that.
After the two-hour roller coaster ride that was the series premiere of Scream Queens, I think it's safe to say that Ryan Murphy has done it again.
he humor is lively for a while, with lots of pop cultural wit, clever insults, and showy guest stars... before it all becomes pretty tiresome.
Emma Roberts is hard to watch for two hours as an uber-bitch that's way beyond anything amusing, whose racism as humor is way out of line.
Ryan Murphy wants his shows to do it all, including stuff that's never really worked for him.
This mash-up of horror, comedy, satire and '90s nostalgia is ridiculous, offensive, gross and over the top. And we can't wait for the next episode!
Here's a sentence I never thought I'd write: Ariana Grande does not appear frequently enough on the show.
Secrets & Lies' first season was an exercise in frustration with a bizarre conclusion, and Season 2's mostly clean slate has a chance to course-correct.
The acting and writing make this a series not to miss. You can binge watch the first few episodes and then be a regular viewer from now till the end.

The storyline in this series has a single-mindedness that might leave viewers feeling like the same note is being pounded over and over again, and it's no secret that that's not a recipe for ratings success.
Not having seen the original, it's hard to compare the two series, but the American version seems bloated. Shockers are tossed out here and there, but there is little connective tissue in the story.
Predictable whodunit packs few real surprises.
It's a fairly mundane mystery populated by cardboard characters with poor decision-making skills, starting with Ben, who immediately becomes the prime suspect, and his wife Christy.
Juliette Lewis, once American cinema's liveliest eccentric, is drained of life, which makes her a perfect match for Phillippe's blankness.
Phillipe isn't good, and Lewis is just plain awful. It's hard to imagine a less-convincing portrayal of a police detective.
It's the kind of story that is well told on cable, but here seems stifled by the casting to start.
The mystery is so-so, but Lewis, who has flown largely under the radar since Cape Fear, reminds us of her immense talent.
I enjoyed the first episode, but the second hour had me ready to bail.
Just as suspicion takes a little time to grow and spread, so does sophistication. But this series seems to be in a very big hurry to be over, which almost guarantees that audiences will be too.
Lewis and Philippe have enough chemistry that his underplaying and her overplaying are a match made in whodunnit heaven.
The writing is clunky, Phillippe is stiff and Lewis overacts like a cop in some parody of cop shows.
By keeping the story to one perspective the audience never feels smarter than its characters, resulting in a strong hour of revelations and breadcrumbs.
Despite its faults, ABC's drama is a winner.
Secrets and Lies doesn't need to be some deep exegesis about human frailty or the way we live now. But it doesn't impress on a plot level, either. The action just languishes.

It would be easy to dismiss ABC's latest entry in the "murder in a small town" subgenre, but by shifting its perspective from the investigators to one of the townspeople, the series breathes some life into a tired premise.
This story unfolds as if it were told by someone overdosing on Ambien.
Ultimately, Secrets and Lies is satisfactory. That doesn't mean it's good, or that it can sustain its story for 10 episodes, or most importantly, that it's necessary.
Those who enjoy mysteries and melodramas will find a lot to like about Secrets & Lies, a show that's as interested in the reaction to the crime as it is to the whodunit.
... those of you in need of a regular fix of forensic pathology could do a lot worse than tune in on Tuesday nights to Secrets of the Dead...
Wayward Pines may not be the most unique show on television, but it can be a fun way to spend an hour when the series isn't taking itself too seriously.
While the new main character Theo isn't that interesting, the trajectory of the characters we know and where the story is headed certainly are.
The series launches right into its new direction with confidence, but it's an awfully somber tone being set.

The world left behind is still uniquely appealing and ambitiously high concept: a small town held captive by sinister, self-righteous, fascist teens called the First Generation and encircled by a goblin-infested hellscape? Yes, sign me up please.
Instead of a weird mystery tension... it's quite dull and repetitive.
This may as well be a CW show like The 100 because the show is now only about trying to survive in a post-apocalyptic world where there are things and people always trying to kill you.
A second-season seemed like a good idea. But, like Showtime's The Affair, Wayward - based on the novels by Blake Crouch - was meant to be one-season show.
Season 1 was, at best, a guilty pleasure with a weak ending. Now, you almost feel bad for the series in its second season, limping along, trying to rebuild from what little was left.
I was willing to give Wayward Pines a chance to justify a second season. It simply doesn't do so.
There are definitely more abbies in the second season, but if what you liked about the first was the insidious unknown, that's gone with little to replace it.

Continuing the first season's willingness to sacrifice big names for the sake of keeping viewers off balance, season two introduces and dismisses characters with ruthless glee. Surprising exits and reappearances abound.

The exposition-heavy season premiere violates the first rule of good writing - show, don't tell - but even with all of the chatter about the past, some viewers will still find this new iteration of Wayward Pines pretty confusing.

Dramatically limp and uncharacteristically dull, Wayward Pines' unexpected return is what fans feared: an unnecessary redux whose own pointlessness is drilled home by one repetitive story turn after another.
Based on the early episodes of Wayward Pines, the TV trend may once again have audiences mentioning Shyamalan's name among that pack.

Shyamalan has built his career on pulling the proverbial chair from underneath his viewers, but this is the closest something with his name on it has come to matching the... epiphany of The Sixth Sense.
If you're looking for a network series more substantial than the usual summer fling, consider Wayward Pines, M. Night Shyamalan's episodic mystery thriller.
It is a cult looking for a following, and it's already got me on board as a beady-eyed acolyte.
The elements are here to make Wayward Pines worth a visit as other broadcast shows end their seasons and head off to hiatus for the summer.
Moody mystery has bloody moments and a sinister undertone.
The tone is ominous throughout in a show that provides its share of good jolts.
Welcome to Wayward Pines, where nothing is certain, no one can be trusted, and imitation is not only the highest form of flattery, it's a way of life.
[It] deserves to be taken on its own terms for what it is: a super engaging, extremely fun puzzle.

Wayward Pines is a thrill to watch, totally original with puzzles and clues that suck you in and reveals that illuminate a bit of the truth but only make the rest of the mystery more murky. It's like Lost on Adderall.
Matt Dillon is perfectly cast in the lead, and though some themes and visual cues are a little hokey at first, Wayward Pines soon enough turns into thrilling network television.

Like an especially blatant copycat poseur who yearns desperately to be seen as one of the cool kids, Wayward Pines borrows from the best, which only makes this 10-episode "event" series look worse as it goes.

I love the cast. It's hard not to when it is full of Oscar nominees and winners. Melissa Leo's Nurse Pam is seriously scary. Listening to her describe how Ethan was going to be awake, but immobile, during surgery sent a shudder through me.
Let's just say there's a bait-and-switch here -- but viewers who stick it out will be getting the better part of the deal.
It takes a while - two episodes, at least - for the viewer to really tune into its odd wavelength.
The five episodes provided for review... are puzzling without really being involving.
Mostly it's good, creepy fun, a round-the-fire story of a series that may turn out to be about something bigger than it seems.
It's nice to see Eighties heart-throb Dillon back in a starring role, and his permanently confused facial expression is ideally suited to this series.

Keep your eyes peeled and don't doze off. It's got an all-star cast, a big-name director and it's a mess. A very interesting mess, mind you. You need patience, a sense of humour and a keen eye for the ridiculous.
TV trends converge in Wayward Pines, a familiar-feeling yet addictive thriller arriving Thursday on Fox.
Any display of respect for the medium's elders worthy of its spurs would by rights include more depth than this.
Compared to this year's awful new CBS comedies, Life in Pieces is a gem as its second-season premiere proves.
Perky, well-written, charming alternative to ABC's long-in-the-tooth Modern Family. Life is back for its second season and doesn't miss a beat, with its likable ensemble cast in fine form.
It is so reminiscent of Modern Family that it already feels stale.
This is one of the few broadcast-network sitcoms this season I can imagine checking in on regularly.
The thing is, despite the structure, Life in Pieces doesn't cover any ground that, say, Modern Family already covered better.
Unfortunately, the pilot is pleasant, bland, and doesn't give that great cast material equal to their talents.
While hardly as ambitious an undertaking, there's a hint of Louie in there, where the main story is added to in isolated, well-realized touches rather than conforming to one standard narrative.

The shifts in tone aside, Life in Pieces was a pretty solid comedy built around a deep roster of talent that wasn't afraid to go for the joke, but still managed to come off more mature than most of the network's other comedy options.
Family comedy that never comes together.
This is one of my favorites so far.
There are some welcome faces in the family... and some amusing moments. But they can't get the tone right, moving for the vulgar almost reflexively.

Life in Pieces, a wacky single-camera intergenerational family comedy, is the staid network's attempt to mimic critical darling and ratings bonanza Modern Family, with edgy (for CBS, mind you) laughs and a squishy heartwarming beat at the end.

It's a finish more sitcommy than the show seems to call for, but one not weak enough to upset the balance of funny and heartfelt that made me want to see a bit more, even if it was just for the pleasure of this company.
Surprisingly unrelatable as a family sitcom.
Even at its most outrageous, Life in Pieces feels padded with foam.

The obvious irony of the series is that Life in Pieces purports to be about the small, seemingly innocuous moments that linger longest in one's memory, while offering audiences absolutely none of those moments itself.
Nor is [Life in Pieces] different enough to shake that nagging feeling that you're simply watching CBS's attempt to clone ABC's hit.
Life in Pieces just needs to hone the show around its ensemble until it becomes worthy of its stars.
I'm still rather iffy on Life In Pieces, but I'm willing to give it a chance and see where the next few episodes take us.
CBS' "Life in Pieces" puts a strong cast through an obvious variation on "Modern Family." Yet the cast is a draw, and James Brolin stands out as the loopy patriarch.
The shortcoming, at least from the evidence of the premiere, is likely to be in the story selection.
The show has novelty on its side, but it also has a talented ensemble that's under (by a guesstimate) half of the time crunch of the average sitcom cast.
